ORDER

This is an application filed under Section 482 of the Bharatiya Nagarik
Suraksha Sanhita, seeking pre-arrest bail.

2. The petitioner is alleged to have committed the offences
punishable under Sections 406, 408 and 420 of the Indian Penal Code, and
Crime No. 222/2025 of Pozhiyoor Police Station is registered against the
petitioner arraying her as the accused.

Criminal M.C.No.611/2025 1/6

3. The prosecution allegation in brief is as follows:- The accused,
who was the staff of D.V.Finance, an institution run by the defacto complainant,
with an intention to obtain wrongful gain and to cause wrongful loss to the
defacto complainant, during the period from 12.09.2022 to 01.02.2025, made
forged entries showing that 71 customers pledged their gold ornaments and
availed a total sum of Rs.31,77,976/- towards gold loans, and obtained the
balance amount of Rs.1,96,722/- kept in the institution, and thus obtained a total
sum of Rs.33,74,698/- from the institution.

4. Notice in this bail application is issued to the Public Prosecutor.
The Investigating Officer filed report opposing the anticipatory bail application.

5. Heard. Perused the records.

6. The only point to be considered is, whether an order of
anticipatory bail can be granted to the petitioner/ accused.

7. The Point:- The defacto complainant is the Proprietor of an
institution by name “D.V.Finance”, situated at Charottukonam. The petitioner/
accused was the staff of the said institution. It is alleged that, the
petitioner/accused, during the period from 12.09.2022 to 01.02.2025, made
forged entries in the register showing that they allotted a total sum of
Rs.31,77,976/- towards gold loans to 71 persons, and _ she obtained
Rs.1,96,722/-, which was kept in the institution, and thus obtained a total sum of

Criminal M.C.No.611/2025 2/6

Rs.33,74,698/- from the institution, and thereby cheated the defacto
complainant.

8. The petitioner submits that, she was working as a Clerk in the
Devaram Kurries Private Limited, Plamoottukada, since 22.11.2006, and on
14.09.2022, she had joined in the Charottukonam Branch, and one Vijayan D.,
the Managing Director of the said firm had filed a petition to the Station House
Officer, Pozhiyoor Police Station alleging that the petitioner had committed
financial misappropriation while she was working in the said institution. It is
submitted that, the actual fact is that, in December 2024, the petitioner
informed the Managing Director of Devaram Kurries that, she is going to
resign from her job because of some illness and she had made a claim of
Rs.4,32,000/- towards her provident fund benefits. It is also submitted that, the
petitioner resigned from D.V.Finance on 01.02.2025, and thereafter, in order to
evade from the payment of the provident fund benefits, the said Vijayan had
fabricated a story against the petitioner, and by influencing the Pozhiyoor
Police, he is trying to implicate the petitioner in this case. The defacto
complainant also filed a complaint against one Tharakumari, who was the staff
of the institution, for the above said reasons. The petitioner is suffering from
various diseases. The petitioner produced the copies of the medical records and
copy of screen shot of text message from South Indian Bank, to substantiate her
contentions.

Criminal M.C.No.611/2025 3/6

9. There is serious allegation as against the petitioner. Going by the
First Information Statement given by the defacto complainant, it is seen that,
while working with D.V.Finance Company, the petitioner had cheated the
defacto complainant by fraudulently entering in the register that the customers
had pledged the gold ornaments and appropriating the money given by the
Company for her own purpose. It is also stated in the First Information
Statement that the Day Book Register and Gold Pledging Register were
maintained and the misappropriation was traced out when the petitioner asked
for advance amount to be paid to the customer and on verification of the Gold
Pledge Register, the defacto complainant came to know of the
misappropriation. The contention of the petitioner is that she was only a Clerk
in that institution and that the Managing Director was the custodian of the
locker, and the cash and gold locker were not handled by the petitioner. It is
also stated by the petitioner that regular audits were conducted by the officials
of the company and if at all any financial misappropriation is noticed, it would
have been revealed in audit reports. Apparently, the prosecution has not
brought out any materials to show the commission of the offence by the
petitioner. In the report submitted by the Investigating Officer, nothing is
stated relating to the seizure of any documents, at least the so called Gold
Pledge Register or Day Book Register. Even in the First Information Statement
given by the defacto complainant, there is no clarity as to the functioning of the

Criminal M.C.No.611/2025 4/6

institution and how the petitioner had cheated the defacto complainant. It is not
clear whether without verification of the pledged gold, any amount was
advanced by the company. Significantly, the petitioner is only the Clerk of the
institution and nothing is stated in the First Information Statement why the
activities of the petitioner is not managed by the superior officers or by way of
audit for such a long period. The prosecution has not made out a prima facie
case as against the petitioner. It would be a travesty of justice, if the petitioner
is put behind the bars, if she has not committed any offence. No criminal
antecedents of the petitioner is brought to the notice of this court.

10. In view of my discussion above, it appears that there is no
impediment in granting a pre-arrest bail to the petitioner. Considering all these
aspects, it is found that this is a fit case where a pre-arrest bail can be granted to
the petitioner.

In the result, the petition is allowed

In the result, the petition is allowed on the following conditions:-

(1) In the event of arrest, the petitioner/ accused shall be
released on bail on her executing bond for Rs.50,000/-
(Rupees Fifty Thousand only) with two solvent sureties for
the like sum each to the satisfaction of the arresting
officer/Investigating Officer, as the case may be.

(2) Petitioner shall appear before the Investigating Officer
between 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. on every Wednesday for a
period of 3 (three) months or till the filing of the final
report, whichever is earlier.

Criminal M.C.No.611/2025 5/6

(3) Petitioner shall also appear before the Investigating Officer
as and when required.

(4) Petitioner shall not commit any offence while on bail.

(5) Petitioner shall not attempt to contact the defacto
complainant or any of the prosecution witnesses, directly

or through any other person, or in any other way try to

tamper with the evidence or influence any witnesses or

other persons related to the investigation.

(6) Even when the petitioner is on anticipatory bail, the
petitioner will be deemed to be in custody for the purpose

of effecting any recovery, etc., as held by the Hon’ble

Supreme Court in Sushila Agarwal and Others v. State

(2020 ICO 108).

In case of any violation of the above conditions or misuse of
liberty, the prosecution or the defacto complainant is at liberty to approach
jurisdictional court for cancellation of bail.
